cluster except it's smaller and has different options for development
so let's talk a little bit about those so a local cluster first question uh can my app fit my laptop's ram because if

if your internet speed is not very fast that doesn't really matter uh and that's

and then they choose okay the car services plus this the car services plus that or plus the other thing
and that means that okay they can't run the whole application in their development environment but they can run

okay um let's move on to the next section managing config files so
if you're editing a ton of vml files by hand you're basically coding a notepad uh it's a big headache
every time you make a change to anything on kubernetes you're going to have to replicate that change in a bunch of other email files and we're humans and
our brains are not very big so we're going to forget and get in trouble and lose a whole day trying to debug it so
instead you should use a templating solution and if you don't know what that is it's basically you have a template on the
left you make a change to whatever you want on the template and it generates all the end result yaml for you so you
don't have to keep 30 different yaml files in mind you can just change something on the template
and it generates the results for you so datadog they use helm for templating
um of course the templates have different environments so you know if you're in production you maybe want 100
replicas of something but if you're in in development you just want one
uh basically developers write the email template uh the first time they set up a
service or maybe when they need to tweak some settings but generally developers don't mess with ymo day in day out
someone sets up the template the first time no one else cares about it forever again
and there's some integration with tilts and i'm going to talk about those a little bit later
so mindspace they have a fun trick so they use helm templating of course but in addition to that because they're such
a tiny company they have an advantage that datadog doesn't which is all their services are basically all the configs
are copy pasted from each other and you just change the name of the image i'm oversimplifying of course but that is
kind of the gist of it so you keep everything structurally very similar uh and that gives you a lot of um
flexibility later on that i'm going to talk about in the next session uno does the same thing
but they do some other stuff on top so that basically uh individual developers can customize
their own settings on top of the template so you're not stuck with the template
so they have a kind of a methodical way to do that cluster api again the same thing
services are very uniform structurally similar there are ways for users to override the

is that is kind of the the story so i don't care how big or how small you
are if you're developing code and doing more than just a weekend prototype for fun use a templating solution uh

uh if i'm that developer i'm going to be very tired with all the context switching and being unable to

using the typical basically by hand processes um

there are usually two workflows that these tools use to automate uh this stuff so the conventional workflow which
was basically the first one that came along it's like there's a file watcher looking over your
project you make a change it rebuilds the image of that service uh ships it to
a registry and replaces it inside the cluster and it does everything automatically you as a developer don't
need to do anything you just save your file when you make a change and there it is uh the problem with this approach is
that because you need to rebuild an image and redeploy an image uh and you know if your internet's bad uh shipping
the image so a registry is also gonna take some time so this can take a little bit of time and
there's a lot of unnecessary your computer gets tired basically
the the newer approach which most of these tools support now is live updates which basically means you change your
code i'm going to live sync that file into a container somewhere inside the
container i'm going to recompile or rebuild or restart the process or something like that
that's much faster generally again i've given whole talks about this it's complicated this is an
